episodeTitle: The Forbidden Sacred Ground! The Island Where God Lives and Heaven's Judgment!
episodeTitleJapanese: 禁断の聖地！神の住む島と天の裁き！
episodeTitleRomanized: Kindan no Seichi! Kami no Sumu Shima to Ten no Sabaki!
description: Conis explains the forbidden Upper Yard and the almighty God Enel who rules Skypiea. Nami ventures into the forest and witnesses Enel's devastating power. Meanwhile, the White Berets arrive to enforce Heaven's Judgment on the Straw Hats for their illegal entry.

events.title: Enel's Divine Rule Explained
events.description: Conis explains to the Straw Hats that Skypiea is ruled by an almighty God named Enel who constantly monitors all inhabitants. She describes how Enel knows everything that happens on the island by always watching them.
events.significance: Introduces the main antagonist of the Skypiea Arc and establishes the theocratic control system of the sky island. This sets up the central conflict of the arc.

quotes.text: Skypiea is ruled by almighty God Enel, who knows everything that goes on in the world by always watching us.
quotes.speaker: Conis
quotes.context: Explaining Skypiea's government to the Straw Hats

events.title: Upper Yard Forbidden Zone Revealed
events.description: Pagaya warns that Upper Yard is a forbidden sacred ground where God resides. He states that anyone who enters the forest would not come back alive, establishing it as the most dangerous area in Skypiea.
events.significance: Establishes Upper Yard as the primary location for the arc's main conflicts and foreshadows the dangers the Straw Hats will face.

quotes.text: Anyone visiting Upper Yard would not come back alive.
quotes.speaker: Pagaya
quotes.context: Warning the Straw Hats about the dangers of the forbidden zone

events.title: Straw Hats React to God Concept
events.description: The Straw Hats display varied philosophical reactions to the concept of God. Chopper shows innocent wonder, Zoro demonstrates religious indifference, Sanji demands evidence, and Luffy jokes about breaking rules.
events.significance: Character development moment showing each crew member's worldview and skepticism toward authority, foreshadowing their defiant stance against Enel.

quotes.text: I don't care whether or not a god exists.
quotes.speaker: Zoro
quotes.context: Expressing his agnosticism to Chopper's surprise

quotes.text: God will forgive you if you break the law.
quotes.speaker: Luffy
quotes.context: Joking about entering the forbidden zone

events.title: The Four Priests Debut
events.description: God's four priests - Ohm, Satori, Shura, and Gedatsu - are formally introduced as they chase an illegal treasure hunter through Upper Yard. They represent Enel's primary enforcers.
events.significance: Introduces the main antagonists the Straw Hats will face in trials. Each priest guards a different ordeal that must be overcome.

events.title: Enel's Lightning Power Demonstrated
events.description: Nami witnesses Enel's devastating power as a massive beam of lightning fires from the sky and completely disintegrates an illegal treasure hunter. This demonstrates Enel's God-like abilities and his Goro Goro no Mi Devil Fruit power.
events.significance: First demonstration of Enel's terrifying lightning powers and establishes him as an incredibly dangerous antagonist. Shows that Enel can strike anywhere on the island.

events.title: Masked Warrior Appears
events.description: A masked guerrilla fighter with a bazooka appears and fires at the priests near Upper Yard. This figure is later revealed to be Wyper, a Shandia warrior fighting to reclaim their homeland.
events.significance: Introduces the Shandia resistance and foreshadows the complex three-way conflict between Enel's forces, the Shandia, and the Straw Hats.

events.title: Vearth Mentioned
events.description: The masked warrior expresses resentment toward Enel over something called 'Vearth', hinting at the underlying conflict over the sacred soil of Upper Yard.
events.significance: Introduces the concept of Vearth (earth/soil) as the most valuable resource in Skypiea and the cause of the 400-year war.

events.title: McKinley and White Berets Arrive
events.description: Captain McKinley leads the White Berets, Skypiea's police force, to Angel Beach to investigate the illegal trespassing by the Straw Hat Pirates who entered without paying the entry toll.
events.significance: McKinley debuts as the law enforcement captain and escalates the conflict. Introduces the White Berets as Skypiea's marines.

quotes.text: We are here to bestow Heaven's Judgment upon you.
quotes.speaker: McKinley
quotes.context: Announcing their intent to punish the Straw Hats

events.title: Crime Class Escalation Begins
events.description: McKinley reveals the Straw Hats are Class 11 criminals for illegal entry. He offers to reduce their crime to tourist status if they pay ten times the entry fee, but the situation quickly escalates.
events.significance: Establishes Skypiea's crime classification system and sets up the escalating conflict that will force the Straw Hats to face the priests.

events.title: Nami Attacks McKinley
events.description: After learning about the massive fine, Nami gets so angry that she drives her Waver straight into McKinley's face, sending him flying. This escalates their crime from Class 11 to Class 5.
events.significance: Nami's impulsive action dramatically worsens their situation, changing their punishment from a fine to a death sentence via 'drifting cloud'.

events.title: Drifting Cloud Death Penalty
events.description: McKinley announces the Class 5 punishment of 'drifting cloud' - being placed on a small cloud that drifts endlessly in the sky with no chance of escape, effectively a death sentence.
events.significance: Reveals Skypiea's unique punishment methods that utilize their cloud-based environment.

events.title: White Berets Attack with Dials
events.description: The White Berets attack the Straw Hats using cloud arrows and Dial weapons, showcasing Skypiea's unique combat technology for the first time.
events.significance: First demonstration of Dial technology in combat, introducing the unique weapons and tools used by Skypieans.

events.title: Straw Hats Defeat White Berets
events.description: Luffy, Zoro, and Sanji easily defeat the White Berets and their Dial weapons, demonstrating the power difference between Blue Sea pirates and Skypiea's police force.
events.significance: Shows that while Dials are new technology, the Straw Hats' combat experience gives them an advantage. However, this victory escalates their crime status.

events.title: Class 2 Criminals Declared
events.description: A bloodied McKinley warns the Straw Hats that by defeating the White Berets, they have become Class 2 criminals and will now be judged by the relentless Priests of Upper Yard.
events.significance: Final escalation that forces the Straw Hats into direct conflict with Enel's priests. This effectively seals their fate to enter Upper Yard and face the trials.

quotes.text: You are now Class 2 criminals. You will be judged by the Priests of Upper Yard!
quotes.speaker: McKinley

quotes.text: Skypiea is ruled by almighty God Enel, who knows everything that goes on in the world by always watching us.
quotes.speaker: Conis

quotes.text: Anyone visiting Upper Yard would not come back alive.
quotes.speaker: Pagaya

quotes.text: I don't care whether or not a god exists.
quotes.speaker: Zoro

quotes.text: We are here to bestow Heaven's Judgment upon you.
quotes.speaker: McKinley
quotes.context: Arriving to arrest the Straw Hats

quotes.text: You are now Class 2 criminals. You will be judged by the Priests of Upper Yard!
quotes.speaker: McKinley

themes.description: The episode explores the Straw Hats' defiance of established authority, from their illegal entry to their defeat of the White Berets, demonstrating their rejection of unjust rules.
themes.symbolism: The escalating crime classes represent how challenging corrupt authority inevitably leads to greater conflict.

themes.description: The crew's varied reactions to the concept of God Enel showcase different philosophical approaches to faith, from Chopper's innocent belief to Zoro's indifference and Sanji's demand for proof.
themes.symbolism: The 'god' who must be proven versus believed in represents the clash between blind faith and empirical evidence.

themes.description: Enel's omnipresent surveillance and strict laws contrast sharply with the Straw Hats' pirate freedom, setting up the arc's central ideological conflict.
themes.symbolism: The forbidden Upper Yard represents restricted knowledge and freedom that the Straw Hats will inevitably challenge.

characterSpotlights.development: Nami ventures alone into Upper Yard and witnesses Enel's terrifying power firsthand. Her impulsive attack on McKinley also escalates the crew's situation dramatically.
keyActions: Explores Upper Yard on her Waver

characterSpotlights.development: Zoro's statement about not caring if a god exists reveals his secular worldview and foreshadows his willingness to fight Enel despite his supposed divinity.
quotes: I don't care whether or not a god exists.

characterSpotlights.development: McKinley is introduced as a dutiful captain trying to enforce Skypiea's laws, though he's ultimately outmatched by the Blue Sea pirates.
keyActions: Arrives to arrest the Straw Hats
quotes: We are here to bestow Heaven's Judgment upon you.
You are now Class 2 criminals. You will be judged by the Priests of Upper Yard!

mangaDifferences.difference: The anime extends some scenes of the White Berets' arrival and battle for pacing.

trivia.fact: This episode marks the first appearance of all four of Enel's priests together, though they are only briefly shown.
The concept of Vearth (earth/soil) being precious in the sky islands is a clever inversion of typical treasure in pirate stories.
McKinley's character design includes a scar under his left eye and typical Skypiean wings.
This is the last episode to use 'Free Will' by Ruppina as the ending theme.
